awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: PacketLab: A Universal Measurement Endpoint Interface
awd_abstract_narration:
PacketLab is a universal internet traffic measurement abstraction that lowers barriers faced by both experimenters and operators of internet measurement infrastructures. Internet measurement has had a major impact on science and society broadly, from helping us in identifying network threats like botnets, to providing a factual foundation for discussing internet policy issues. This work aims to serve the needs of the entire network measurement community by developing a universal interface that simplifies network measurement and facilitates resource sharing between research groups. PacketLab will make it easier to share measurement resources, and this will broaden access to these resources by institutions that would normally not have the resources to develop and maintain their own measurement platform.

This project aims to answer several fundamental questions in network measurement including 1) how to express measurement experiments using a small number of measurement primitives; 2) whether experiment logic can be effectively moved off the endpoint conducting the measurement; and 3) how measurement platform operators can ensure conformance to their platform policies while encouraging resource sharing. 
PacketLab is built on two key ideas. First, it moves measurement logic away from the measurement endpoint to a separate experiment control server, making each endpoint a lightweight packet source or sink. Second, it provides a way to delegate access to measurement endpoints while retaining fine-grained control over how endpoints are used by experimenters, allowing research groups to share measurement infrastructure with each other with little overhead.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The PacketLab universal measurement endpoint interface design sought to tackle the known high-cost problems of vantage point sharing faced by Internet measurement researchers. By transforming vantage points into enhanced VPN servers with finer-grained access control mechanisms, PacketLab is an appealing sharing alternative for vantage point operators with lower support costs and more control over shared vantage point capability. At the same time, for measurement experimenters, the same exported interface allows for frictionless porting of measurements across vantage points exporting the interface.
Though promising in theory, the VPN-like nature of PacketLab introduces limitations on measurement feasibility. Measurements may need extra capabilities not exported by the interface or need in-time responses at the vantage point toward network events, both of which PacketLab do not provide. A natural question then follows on how these limitations impact measurements of interest to the Internet measurement community. Project researchers found that most (over 77%) past studies performing active measurement experiments that would benefit from additional vantage points are not affected by PacketLab limitations, showing that PacketLab provides sufficient capabilities for conducting most relevant measurements.
By providing a software package (https://pktlab.github.io) containing experimenter tools and a reference implementation of the PacketLab measurement endpoint, researchers could now use PacketLab to share vantage point access easily. The package is also open source to encourage community involvement in improving the codebase. To further facilitate porting measurements from the external parties, a prototype tool - pktwrap for repurposing existing measurement programs to run over PacketLab via intercepting libc function calls was developed that will be released soon after additional polishing. Overall, PacketLab is now ready to be used by the research community to facilitate future measurement endeavors.


Last Modified: 11/17/2023
Modified by: Kirill Levchenko
